title: Trump Tramples Congress’s Power, With Little Challenge From G.O.P.
summary: On national security, spending and oversight, the president continues to undercut the legislative branch, and Republicans in charge have done little to stop him.

title: Trump Tried to Kill the Infrastructure Law. Now He’s Getting Credit for Its Projects.
summary: Signs bearing President Trump’s name have gone up at major construction projects financed by the 2021 law, which he strenuously opposed ahead of its passage.

title: Tensions Mount as Trump Administration Threatens Federal Crackdown in Chicago
summary: In a social media post, President Trump said Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.” Illinois officials condemned the message.

title: President of Peace, Department of War. A New Name Sends Mixed Signals.
summary: President Trump’s renaming of the Defense Department comes amid his campaign for a Nobel Peace Prize. On Saturday, he wrote on social media that Chicago was “about to find out why it’s called the Department of WAR.”

title: South Korea Negotiates Release of Korean Workers Detained in Georgia Raid
summary: The South Korean government said on Sunday that it would send a charter plane to the United States to retrieve hundreds of workers detained in an immigration raid.

title: Immigration Raid Exposes Tensions From Seoul to Washington to Rural Georgia
summary: The raid at a Georgia plant being built with heavy investment from South Korea reveals strain as a rush to expand manufacturing in the United States clashes with an immigration crackdown.

title: ‘If I Live to 25, I’ve Lived a Good Life’
summary: He started fighting wildfires as a teenager. After inhaling smoke on the front lines for six seasons, he faced an impossible choice.

title: Wildfire Fighters, Unmasked in Toxic Smoke, Are Getting Sick and Dying
summary: The U.S. Forest Service has fought decades of efforts to better protect its crews — sending them into smoke without masks or warnings about the risks.

title: Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba of Japan Says He Will Step Down
summary: The embattled leader is trying to head off a deep split in his party over a right-wing political surge, a weakened economy and turbulent trade relations with the United States.

title: Carrie Underwood’s Lyrical Blitz of the N.F.L.
summary: To customize the musical opener for week after week of “Sunday Night Football,” Underwood rattles through dozens of versions in a marathon recording session.

title: Russian Strike Breaks Through Most Protected Part of Kyiv
summary: The attack set a government building on fire in an area of the Ukrainian capital that is rarely damaged.

title: For Americans in Ukraine, Opportunity and the Lure of Combat
summary: The profile of U.S. volunteers in the Ukrainian military has changed, shifting more toward people without military experience, and those who saw few prospects for them at home.

title: Homeless and Hungry, Gazans Fear a Repeat of 1948 History
summary: Israel’s war in Gaza has displaced most of the 2.2 million Palestinian residents from their homes. Many of them fear it will be permanent, a reprise of the Nakba.

title: As Syria Tries to Move Away From Dictatorship, Signs of Authoritarianism Linger
summary: The ex-rebels now in control of Syria say they are ending rule by fear, overhauling the security and prison systems, and holding elections. But concerns over sectarianism and inclusivity remain.

title: The Spectacular Comeback Tour of Ross Ulbricht, the Founder of Silk Road
summary: Ross Ulbricht, who created the Silk Road dark web marketplace and was serving a life sentence for drug distribution, has embarked on a strange and unexpected comeback after President Trump pardoned him in January.

title: How Andy Roddick’s ‘Served’ Became the Most Popular Tennis Podcast in the US
summary: The former No. 1 tennis player in the world is now at the top of a growing pack of podcasters focused on the sport.

title: String Theory
summary: Today, on the last day of the U.S. Open, we have a chat with a tennis writer.

title: Jean Twenge Is Still Warning Parents About Teens and Screen Time. Is Anyone Listening?
summary: The researcher and author Jean Twenge has a prescription for the harmful effects of screen time on children. If only parents would listen.

title: Man Who Vanished Is Identified 52 Years Later, Bringing ‘Rest’ to His Sisters
summary: Eric Singer left his Ohio home on his bicycle, never to be seen again. With the help of advances in DNA research, he was finally found.

title: In the Battle for Congress, Working-Class Democrats Try a Hardscrabble Pitch
summary: A new crop of candidates has turned away from the aspirational “American dream” message of campaigns past and is leaning into how difficult life can be for working people — including them.

title: Patagonia Changed the Apparel Business. Can It Change Food, Too?
summary: The outdoor apparel maker from California wants to fix farming. The first challenge is convincing consumers to think of it for sardines and beer.

title: Stop Funding Trump’s Takeover
summary: Democrats aren’t powerless, and they don’t have to enable autocracy.

title: It Doesn’t Seem Wise to Let Trump Decide What War Is
summary: We do not kill those merely suspected of being criminals from the air.

title: Powerball Hits $1.8 Billion. Here Are the 10 Biggest U.S. Lottery Jackpots.
summary: Two winning tickets will split the $1.787 billion Powerball jackpot drawn on Saturday. Changes to Powerball and Mega Millions have led to increasingly large jackpots in recent years.

title: Why France’s Financial Woes Are Pushing Its Government to the Brink
summary: The French prime minister has proposed drastic spending cuts and tax increases to shore up the country’s accounts, but his plan could backfire.

title: Why Are More Older People Dying After Falls?
summary: Some researchers suspect that rising prescription drug use may explain a disturbing trend.

title: Why Frequent Flier Programs Have Become Essential to Many Airlines
summary: The biggest U.S. airlines make billions of dollars from their loyalty programs and branded credit cards, which some analysts believe are now essential to the businesses.
